> You know, hmm ....  that is a scary observation that stops me in my
> tracks,
> 'cos I feel I am about to slip. Am I doing this? Hmm, maybe I am. At what
> point does a unit test of an aggregating object, or subclass, become an
> integration test? My head hurts.

IMO there's no strict line nor does it make much sense to be very purist
here. 
For me the question is: When does it hurt to have integration-like tests? It
does hurt when:
- The tests run too long
- Many tests break on a single change/bug
- Many tests in many test classes have to be changed when I change the
interface of a single class
- I have difficulties to understand the setup-code on a single glance

In our projects it often happens like this: We ignore the first symptoms of
tests which are too involved and too "integrated". Suddenly - usually when
doing larger refactorings - we swear at the amount of testing code we have to
change. Then we invest the effort to decouple tests (which usually means to
decouple application code). I wish, however, we wouldn't ignore the early
symptoms in the first place.

Johannes
